captions.text:
Farrell, you and
your brother stand clear.

I got no
interest in you today.

Stand clear,
and you won't get hurt.

You think one on
four's a dogfall?

I mean to kill you
in one minute, ned,

Or see you
hanged in fort smith

I call that bold talk
for a one-eyed fat man.

Fill your hand,
you son of a bitch!

They're too far
and they're moving too fast.

Hooray for
the man from texas!

title: True Grit (9/9) Movie CLIP - Bold Talk for a One-Eyed Fat Man (1969) HD

comments.author: The Cult of Opinion

comments.text:
While I am more of a fan of the 2010 version of True Grit and prefer other 
John Wayne westerns, I like this version of the film pretty well 
also because its fun, has that old fashioned style and innocence that 
earlier westerns did and that was fading around the time it was released, 
beautifully shot, and an overall great cast like Wayne himself, Robert 
Duvall, Dennis Hopper, and Glenn Campbell (if you didn't like his acting, 
you at least could admire his singing the main theme) (Kim Darby did okay 
as well).

I can also see why so many people love it because they grew up with it and 
have great memories of it plus because of the elements mentioned above and 
I'd love to see if not at least a comeback for the Western genre, at least 
another popular Western made in this lighter old fashioned idealic style. 
Plus, while I do prefer the 2010 film more, this film actually did some 
elements/moments better in my opinion like this scene above. Just Wayne's 
facial reaction, the delivery of his response and his charge into battle 
made the scene so effective, funny, and exhilarating at the same time.

With the 2010 version, it just felt like something was missing, but overall 
it captured the spirit and intentions the original book was going for.﻿

comments.author: Thomas Templeton

comments.text:
If you've ever read the book, this movie is absolutely terrible. The 
setting is wrong, Glen Campbell can't act, Kim Darby portrays the most 
annoying 14 year old girl you could imagine, and the ending is strange and 
wrong. It's an okay movie if you have no knowledge of the book and just 
want to see John Wayne shoot some shit a couple times. His portrayal of 
Rooster kind of sucks too. I don't usually like remakes over originals, but 
the 2010 version is superior in capturing the tone of the book, and the 
acting is much better all around.﻿

comments.text:
Actually, Kim Darby's portrayal was *absolutely spot-on*!! In the book, 
Mattie Ross goes out of her way to be irritating and high-handed on every 
single dad-blasted page. Not for nothing is she told by the outsmarted 
horse-auctioneer, "You are an unnatural child!" Loved the book, and (minus 
Glen You-know-who) loved the movie!
comments.author: CLASSICALFAN100

comments.text:
If you  want it to be like the book, READ THE BOOK! Don't watch the film! 
Many film adaptions are better than the books (notably films of the works 
of Jane Austen, Charles Dickens, and John Steinbeck), but a lot of people 
who have read the books cannot get past the fact that the film does not 
match the book. BTW- every time you talk to anyone, ever, and they have 
read the book and seen the movie while you have only seen the film, they 
will say the book is better. Every time, without exception. I have gone 
back and read books after seeing the film, and often found the books to be 
inferior (notably on Nicholas Sparks books), thus wasted a lot of time 
reading books which people claimed were better.
comments.author: Casey Vee

two different films, they're both good in their own ways.

comments.text:
Box Office is the measuring stick....without it we have only 
opinion....your analysis on John Wayne...you don't like him as much as 
Clint so you discount the fact that he is America's most successful Box 
Office Actor..... like the Elvis Presley haters who say the Beatles are 
better in terms of success, yet Elvis sold more records and had two times 
as many Top 40 Hits as the Beatles...some fans don't think that 
matter....statistically John Wayne is more successful than Clint 
Eastwood.... FACT
comments.author: Bill Tidy

comments.text:
Box office does not equal greatest. In fact, some people prefer Clint's 
westerns, because they're actually ahead of their time without the cheesy 
music scores and monotone delivery. I'm one of the people who prefer 
Clint's movies. But I recognize that there are people who enjoy Wayne's 
more. You can't claim one is better than the other. But overall, Clint's 
revisionist westerns do stand up better when compared to modern cinema. 
Less cheese, that is all.
comments.author: IronRooRoo

comments.text:
You mean no one will ever deliver it as flat and monotone as Wayne? Ok, got 
it.
comments.author: IronRooRoo

comments.text:
I agree. Look at Sergio Leone's dollars trilogy. They were made BEFORE this 
movie, and they have more appropriate cinematography, scores and realistic 
characters. Sorry to say it, but John Wayne's westerns are stuck in that 
cheesy cookie cutter era, and his delivery is not 'perfect'. Not to mention 
this cheerful music during a fight, no atmosphere, LOL! The Good, the Bad 
and the Ugly is superior and way ahead of its time, with an appropriate 
score and mature atmosphere. Eastwood is better.
comments.author: IronRooRoo

comments.author: Delmar Terblanche

comments.text:
I think the music in the remake was suggesting this was Rooster's last 
chance at actual good guy heroism, he's making one big charge and finally 
fighting the good fight.
comments.author: Francis Borek

comments.text:
I rather like that offended look that Cogburn gets after they call him a 
one-eyed fat man. A gesture that speaks for itself, though I imagine what 
it says is mostly "I really am going to have to shoot this dumb bastard."
comments.author: subtlewhatssubtle

comments.text:
It's really interesting to compare this scene to the 2010 version of the 
same moment. The original is far more heroic and noble, both in the way the 
scene is shot and how it's scored - a great traditional, romantic western 
starring the Duke himself. The remake's music is more melancholy, almost as 
if it wishes it were being heroic but it knows it isn't. It doesn't present 
an action scene so much as a tragic grasp at a nobility it knows it can't 
have. Two great but very different films.
comments.author: Delmar Terblanche

comments.text: Troll
comments.author: Rprince418
